Gosu Rules

Lesson
objectives « Explain the functionality of Gosu Rules

* Describe the Gosu techniques unique to
Gosu Rules
« Write Gosu Rules

Gosu Rules

| Gosu rules i

« ARule is a Gosu class with the file extension .gr

« ARule is a single decision in the following form:
If {some conditions} 42
Then {take some actions} Se

¢« Example:

+ If ABPerson doesn’t have an email address, then create a Flag Entry to notify the TrainingApp
users

¢« When an Event happens to an Entity, different set of Rules might be executed by
the Guidewire application

« Example: when ABContact is saved the system runs
* The ABContactPreupdate Rules and
* The ABContactValidation Rules

| Examples in Guidewire applications G

¢ Activity escalation ¢ Claim assignment ¢ Account validation
rules rules rules
* Escalate activity that is « Assign given claim to a * Verify that account is
open for too long group and user valid before committing
* Triggered when activity * Triggered when claim is it to database
is open past its created or needs * Triggered when account

escalation date reassignment is created or modified

| Gosu rule anatomy
* Root entity

+ Input parameter for the rule

¢ Name
+ Unique and follows naming convention

+ Example: ABPU1010 — Contact Created is an
example of a naming convention for Gosu Rules
decided on by the development team if true, | execute action

* Condition
+ Expression that evaluates to true or false
* Action

+ If condition is true, the Guidewire application
executes the action

« If condition is false, nothing happens

Gi
A Gosu Rule consists of a root
entity, an expression that resolves
to true or false, and an action that
is executed if the condition is true

Rules can have child rules

If parent condition is true,
Guidewire executes action and
then executes all child rules

| Rule execution: execute all (1 of 10) Gi

¢ When triggering occurs,

Demonstration

| Demonstration G

Automatically assign flagged contacts

a=
=” “Every new contact with 1 or more flag entries should be assigned to the
creator (logged in user) of the contact for further processing, and a note
— explaining the contact has been automatically assigned - should also
be associated to the contact.”
click here — Insurance company business analysts

Note: The demonstration opens a new tab in your browser. When the demonstration ends, the
original course launch window appears. Return to this window to continue this presentation.

Question G

_— — Whatis the significance of a rule set's root entity?

¢
¢
¢

Sooo ODDODSDoDoOoOoDOoOoOoOSD

Answer a

_— — Whatis the significance of a rule set's root entity?
¢
oY” Every rule set is tied to an entity, known as the root entity. This determines which class
of objects the rule set is tied to. It also determines the object available to the rules in

the rule set when the rule set is triggered.

SOOO ODDDSDoOODDODOoOoS

Question G

_- — Whatis the difference between an "execute all" rule set and an “exit after
Yo first action" rule set?

Sooo ODDODSDoDoOoOoDOoOoOoOSD

Answer a

_— — Whatis the difference between an "execute all" rule set and an “exit after
a first action" rule set?
? In an “execute all" rule set, all rules are executed. For example, validation rule sets are
execute all. All validation conditions are checked, regardless of how many are true. In
an "exit after first action" rule set, you do not typically execute all rules. When the first
true condition is found, the action associated with that condition is taken and the rule
set is exited. For example, assignment rule sets are exit after first action. Once an

assignment is made, the rule set exits so that later code doesn't reassign the object.

SOOO ODDDSDoOODDODOoOoS

Question G

_— — Whatis the effect of deactivating a rule?

¢
¢
¢

Sooo ODDODSDoDoOoOoDOoOoOoOSD

Answer a

_- — Whatis the effect of deactivating a rule?

¢
oY” The rule is not executed by the rules engine, which is useful in development for turning

rules "on" and "off".

SOOO ODDDSDoOODDODOoOoS

Question G

_— — Whatis the significance of a rule set's root entity?

¢
¢
¢

Sooo ODDODSDoDoOoOoDOoOoOoOSD

Answer a

_— — Whatis the significance of a rule set's root entity?
¢
oY” Every rule set is tied to an entity, known as the root entity. This determines which class
of objects the rule set is tied to. It also determines the object available to the rules in

the rule set when the rule set is triggered.

SOOO ODDDSDoOODDODOoOoS

Question G

_- — Whatis the difference between an "execute all" rule set and an “exit after
Yo first action" rule set?

Sooo ODDODSDoDoOoOoDOoOoOoOSD

Answer a

_— — Whatis the difference between an "execute all" rule set and an “exit after
a first action" rule set?
? In an “execute all" rule set, all rules are executed. For example, validation rule sets are
execute all. All validation conditions are checked, regardless of how many are true. In
an "exit after first action" rule set, you do not typically execute all rules. When the first
true condition is found, the action associated with that condition is taken and the rule
set is exited. For example, assignment rule sets are exit after first action. Once an

assignment is made, the rule set exits so that later code doesn't reassign the object.

SOOO ODDDSDoOODDODOoOoS

Question G

_— — Whatis the effect of deactivating a rule?

¢
¢
¢

Sooo ODDODSDoDoOoOoDOoOoOoOSD

Answer a

_- — Whatis the effect of deactivating a rule?

¢
oY” The rule is not executed by the rules engine, which is useful in development for turning

rules "on" and "off".

SOOO ODDDSDoOODDODOoOoS
